title: My Lab Journal
text: This is a template example for lab journaling. Students in the data science courses at the Institute of Entrepreneurship will use this template to learn R for business analytics. Students can replace this text as they wish.

title: My Lab Journal
text:
How to use

Accept the assignment and get your own github repo.
Blog/journal what you are doing in R, by editing the .qmd files.
See the links page for lots of helpful links on learning R.
Change everything to make it your own.
Make sure to render you website every time before you want to upload changes.

title: Probability Theory
text:
Assignment-I

pS = 0.3              #scope to be changed
pTWhenS = 0.2         #'on time' when scope changes
pTNotWhenS = 0.8      #'not on time' when scope changes

pSNot = 0.7           #scope to not be changed
pTWhenSNot = 0.6      #'on time' when scope does not change
pTNotWhenSNot = 0.4   #'not on time' when scope does not change


pTAndS = pS * pTWhenS                 #'change in scope' and 'on time'
print(pTAndS)

#> [1] 0.06



pTAndSNot = pSNot * pTWhenSNot         #'no change in scope' and 'on time'
print(pTAndSNot)

#> [1] 0.42



pTNotAndS = pS * pTNotWhenS            #'change in scope' and 'not on time'
print(pTNotAndS)

#> [1] 0.24



pTNotAndSNot = pSNot * pTNotWhenSNot   #'no change in scope' and 'not on time'
print(pTNotAndSNot)

#> [1] 0.28



totalProbability = pTAndS + pTAndSNot + pTNotAndS + pTNotAndSNot
print(totalProbability)

#> [1] 1




Assignment-II



Use of application depending on the device



#percentages according to devices used
onlySmartphone <- 42.3
onlyTablet <- 27.8
onlyComputer <- 10.0
smartphoneAndTablet <- 7.3
tabletAndComputer <- 3.3
computerAndSmartphone <- 8.8
allThreeDevices <- 0.5


#What is the percentage of customers using all three devices?
allThreeDevices

#> [1] 0.5



#What is the percentage of customers using at least two devices?
atleastTwoDevices <- smartphoneAndTablet + tabletAndComputer + computerAndSmartphone + allThreeDevices
print(atleastTwoDevices)

#> [1] 19.9



#What is the percentage of customers using only one device?
onlyOneDevice <- onlySmartphone + onlyTablet + onlyComputer
print(onlyOneDevice)

#> [1] 80.1




Assignment-III

# A: Faulty product and A': Flawless product
# B: Alarm triggered and B': No Alarm
# P(B|A): Probability of alarm when the product is faulty
# P(B'|A'): Probability of no alarm when the product is flawless
# P(B|A'): Probability of alarm when the product is flawless
# P(A'|B): Probability of flawless product when the alarm is triggered
# P(A|B): Probability of faulty product when the alarm is triggered

alarmWhenFaulty <- 0.97 #P(B|A)
noAlarmWhenFlawless <- 0.99 #P(B'|A')
alarmWhenFlawless <- 1 - noAlarmWhenFlawless #P(B|A')
faulty <- 0.04 #P(A)
flawless <- 1 - faulty #P(A')


# P(A'|B)
flawlessProductWhenAlarm <- (alarmWhenFlawless * flawless)/(alarmWhenFlawless * flawless + alarmWhenFaulty * faulty)
print(flawlessProductWhenAlarm)

#> [1] 0.1983471



# P(A|B)
faultyProductWhenAlarm <- (alarmWhenFaulty * faulty)/(alarmWhenFlawless * flawless + alarmWhenFaulty * faulty)
print(faultyProductWhenAlarm)

#> [1] 0.8016529


These results show that in case the alarm is triggered, there is a possibility of about 19.83% that the product is flawless and a probability of 80.16% that the product is faulty.

title: Probability Theory (submitted by Azeem Abrar Khan)
Statistical Concepts
text:
For each variable, compute the following values. You can use the built-in functions or use the mathematical formulas.

expected value
variance
standard deviation



random_vars <- readRDS("../data/random_vars.rds")
random_vars %>% summarise(expectedAge = mean(age), varianceAge = var(age), stdAge = sd(age))



  




random_vars %>% summarise(expectedIncome = mean(income), varianceIncome = var(income), stdIncome = sd(income))



  




Explain, if it makes sense to compare the standard deviations.

No!, because standard deviation only represents how far the samples are from the sample-mean. Whereas, covariance is the measure of linear dependency, but it can not be compared easily. Correlation can have value form -1 to 1 and can be used instead to interpret the relationship between two quantities.

Then, examine the relationship between both variables and compute:

covariance
correlation



random_vars %>% summarise(covariance = cov(age,income), correlation = cor(age,income))



  




What measure is easier to interpret? Please discuss your interpretation.

As stated above, covariance is not easy interpret, therefore, correlation is easier to interpret.

Compute the conditional expected value for:

E[income | age <= 18]
E[income | age \(\epsilon\) [18,65)]
E[income | age >= 65]



# E[income | age <= 18]
mean(random_vars %>% filter(age<=18) %>% select(income) %>% pull(income))

#> [1] 389.6074



# E[income | age Ïµ [18,65)]
mean(random_vars %>% filter(age>=18 & age<65) %>% select(income) %>% pull(income))

#> [1] 4685.734



# E[income | age >= 65]
mean(random_vars %>% filter(age>=65) %>% select(income) %>% pull(income))

#> [1] 1777.237
